doc.abstracts: In November 1989, Nancy Birdsall was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by John P. Lewis, Richard Webb, and Devesh Kapur. This report contains the notes of that oral interview. During her tenure at the Bank from 1979 to 1993, Mrs. Birdsall worked in the following areas: in the development economics department as an economist (1979-1982); in the country policy department as a senior economist (1982-1984); in the population, health, and nutrition department, policy and research division, as chief (1984-1987); in the Brazil department, population and human resources, operations division, as chief (1987-1990); in the Latin American region department, environment division as chief (1990-1991); and in the policy research department as director (1991-1993). Her transcript notes changes of the World Bank during the decades of the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s, concerning basic leadership needs, structural and departmental adjustment, and sustainable development, respectively. She discusses recommendations for reorganization and states that the “golden age” of the bank is probably over.
